 The Pacers were crushing the Pistons by double-digits. Artest's 24 points and his defense was a major reason for the blow-out. He was the Pacers leading scorer that night.
 
 Ben Wallace of the Detroit Pistons got away with a foul on Artest (i.e. the refs did not call it). On other end of the floor with 45 seconds left, Ron Artest of the Indiana Pacers was called for a foul on Ben Wallace.
 
 Wallace expressed his displeasure by shoving Artest. It was a two-handed shove. Artest walked away towards the scorer's table while Wallace had to be calmed down.
 
 At this point, Artest is at the scorer's table. A man with a criminal background (let's call him convict) allegedly threw a cup filled with ice and beer at the scorers' table. Ice, if you didn't know already, is the solid form of water. Let's stop downplaying the actions of the convict by conveniently neglecting the ice that was in the cup. The convict did not simply pour beer on Artest. The convict threw ice as well.
 
 The convict was successful in hitting Artest (beer-hit). Whether that was his intention, we will probably never know. But the result was that Artest was hit. Artest reacted by going into the stands. However, he did know, at the time, who was responsible.
 
 Artest saw a fan jumping up and down, celebrating the beer-hit. Let's call this fan the cheerleader. Artest ran towards the cheerleader. The cheerleader was apparently yelling "It wasn't me" or something to that effect. Artest may have believed him as Artest did not throw a punch. Artest was attempting to back off but was prevented by the hostile crowd who was grabbing him.
 
 Stephen Jackson of the Pacers was rushing to the scene. One of the fans in the hostile crowd threw beer at Artest's face. Jackson attempted to express his displeasure with this second beer-thrower. 
 
 The convict, noted earlier, grabbed Artest and proceeded to slug Artest in the back of the head. Artest retaliated. At this point, Artest throws his first punch. The convict lost his balance and was falling so Artest's first punch was merely a quick, downward jab. But in any case, Artest made contact with the convict who started the brawl.
 
 The convict and Artest were separated and Artest was escourted back on the court. While heading towards the bench, another fan wearing a Piston jersey (let's call him George) walked up to Artest to challenge him to a fight. Artest threw a right jab at George's jaw that connected. George appeared to be unphased by it. Artest hit him again while another fan -- assumed to be George's friend -- tackled Artest by the legs. Let's call this fan Crazy Legs.
 
 Jermaine O'Neal of the Pacers with a running head start attempted to strike Crazy Legs on the head. Foruntately for Crazy Legs, O'Neal lost his balance but did manage to connect.
 
 Through it all, nobody was seriously injured.
